p: The different levels of pandemic risk observed in our two models stem from their underlying contact networks. To illustrate this, we use nodes and edges to represent individuals and contacts between individuals, respectively. The degree of a node is defined as the number of edges connecting it to other nodes. The homogeneous model assumes that all individuals have the same number of contacts; the empirical model assumes realistic variation in degree [ 65]. We constrained the two models to have the same total number of nodes and empirically-derived mean degree, and, consequently, the same total number of edges.
